course_info:
PHY203: ELEMENTARY PHYSICS I (Fall 2024)

Instructor: Miquel Dorca
Office: 211 East Hall
Email: miquel@uri.edu
Office Hours: MWF 12:30pm -1:00pm

Lecture Times: MWF 1pm-1:50pm (East Hall Auditorium)

Course Description: Calculus-based introduction to Newtonian mechanics. Topics include kinematics and dynamics of particles and systems of particles, conservation laws, rotational motion, gravitation, and oscillatory motion.

Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent enrollment in MTH 141 and concurrent enrollment in PHY 273.

Intended for science and engineering majors.

Textbook: University Physics (OpenStax), 1st Edition, Volume 1. Available for free at https://openstax.org/subjects/science.

Course Goals:
1. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of kinematics.
2. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of forces.
3. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of work, energy, and energy conservation.
4. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of linear momentum and its conservation.
5. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of rotational kinematics, rotational dynamics, and angular momentum conservation.
6. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of oscillations and simple harmonic motion.

General Education Areas: This course satisfies URI's general education areas: "Scientific, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematical Disciplines" (Full); and "Mathematical, Statistical, or Computational Strategies" (Partial).

Learning Outcomes:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the basic concepts of classical mechanics.
2. Apply a conceptual understanding of classical mechanics to physics problems.
3. Develop problem-solving strategies and techniques appropriate to classical mechanics.
4. Carry out quantitative solutions of classical mechanics problems.
5. Carry out, analyze, and present the results of classical mechanics laboratory experiments.

Brightspace: The class will use Brightspace for class announcements and all lectures will be posted there. If the course needs to go remote (e.g., due to a weather cancellation), lectures will be given asynchronously on Brightspace, except on November 25th, 27th, and December 2nd where it will be asynchronous regardless of cancellations.

Instructor Contact Details:
Email: miquel@uri.edu
Office: 211 East Hall
Office Hours: MWF 12:30pm -1:00pm

assignments:
Homework Assignments will be due on or before (usually Wednesdays or Fridays) of almost every week by 10 p.m. and will be administered through WebAssign.

Details:
- HW #1 due Wed., Sept. 11
- HW #2 due Wed., Sept. 18
- HW #3 due Fri., Sept. 25
- HW #4 due Fri., Oct. 4
- HW #5 due Fri., Oct. 18
- HW #6 due Fri., Oct. 25
- HW #7 due Fri., Oct. 30
- HW #8 due Wed., Nov. 6
- HW #9 due Wed., Nov. 13
- HW #10 due Wed., Dec. 4
- HW #11 due Wed., Dec. 11
- HW #12 due Wed., Dec. 11

WebAssign Details:
- Access and purchase at http://webassign.net/student.html
- Class Key: uri13731043
- Students enroll using the class key with their own user IDs and passwords.
- 5 submission attempts allowed per assignment.
- 4-day extension with a 10-point penalty available once per assignment after due date.
- Each student receives a unique set of problem numbers and answers.
- 2-week free grace period to familiarize with WebAssign.

Homework Policy:
- Submit by 10 p.m. due date.
- Different problem sets per student.
- Extensions available with penalties as specified.
exams:
There will be three unit exams and a cumulative final exam.

Exam Details:
- All exams are closed book; only calculators and allowed formula sheets can be used.
- Unit Exams:
  - Unit Exam 1: Chaps. 1, 3, 4 on Fri., Sep. 27
  - Unit Exam 2: Chaps. 5-8 on Fri., Oct. 25
  - Unit Exam 3: Chaps. 9-11, 15 on Wed., Dec. 11
- Final Exam:
  - Comprehensive covering Chaps. 1-11, 15
  - Date: To Be Announced (TBA)
  - If a part of the final exam score is higher than the corresponding unit exam score, it replaces the unit score in the semester grade calculation.
  - Final exam scores do not replace unit exam scores if lower.

Exam Format:
- Closed book with permitted calculators.
- Formula sheets:
  - Unit Exams: 1 sheet per exam
  - Final Exam: 3 sheets

Note: If the course goes remote, the exam schedule and grading scheme may be modified.

special_sessions:
PHY273: LABORATORY AND RECITATION FOR ELEMENTARY PHYSICS I

Components:
1. Laboratory
2. Recitation

Recitation:
- Separate enrollment required.
- Held in Room 112.
- Recitation grade counts toward PHY203 grade (up to 250 points).
- No separate letter grade for PHY273 recitation.
- Must solve 3 problems in each recitation to receive full credit; extra problems can cover missed ones from previous sessions.

Laboratory:
- Separate enrollment for laboratory sections.
- Laboratory Schedule:
  - Intro Lab: 9/9-13
  - 1. Motion in 1D (free fall): 9/16-20
  - 1. Motion in 1D (analysis): 9/23-27
  - 2. Motion in 2D (projectiles): 9/30-10/4
  - 2. Motion in 2D (analysis): 10/7-11
  - 3. Newton's laws: 10/14-18
  - 4. Conservation of Energy: 10/21-25
  - 5. Collisions (experiment): 10/28-11/1
  - 5. Collisions (analysis): 11/4-15
  - 6. Ballistic Pendulum: 11/18-22
  - 7. Rotational dynamics: 12/2-12/6
  - Make-up Lab (Pendulum): 12/12 (Reading Day)
- Lab Registration:
  - Register for one of the 000x laboratory sections and one of the R0x recitation sections.
- Make-up Labs:
  - Only one make-up lab available at the end of the semester for missed experiments, with prior permission from the TA.
- Lab Requirements:
  - Purchase lab manual in advance or at first lab meeting.
  - Bring an acceptable lab notebook (e.g., National Brand Computation Notebook, Model number 43-648) to the first lab meeting.

Additional Special Sessions:
- COVID-19 related adjustments as per university guidelines.
- Academic Enhancement Center resources available for academic support.
